--- title: "Welcome To My Blog Template" author: "Girika" date: "2022-07-18" categories: [news] bibliography: references.bib --- ## Problem Nitrate supports aquatic life at natural levels but in excess drives algal blooms and hypoxia. Managers need a **quick way** to know *when* nitrate spikes and whether **routine sensors** (conductivity, turbidity, dissolved oxygen, temperature, stage) can stand in for expensive nitrate probes. This post **recasts my Assignment 2 analysis** into an accessible summary: one clear figure, one compact table, and a practical takeaway. ## Analysis **Data source.** NEON river sites — Arikaree (CO), Caribou (AK), Lewis Run (VA); nitrate by **SUNA V2** (~15-min), with routine sensors at similar cadence. **Approach** In A2 I fitted **GAMMs** linking nitrate to routine sensors and time structure. For the blog: one clear **figure** + one **table** and what they mean. ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![Nitrate contrasts by site (median, µM).](index_files/figure-html/fig-nitrate-1.png){#fig-nitrate width=672} ::: ::: ::: {#tbl-nitrate .cell tbl-cap='Compact summary of site medians (µM), days measured, and share of total.'} ::: {.cell-output-display} `````{=html}
Site Median (µM) Days measured High days Share of total
Arikaree (CO) 5.5 120 18% 2%
Caribou (AK) 28.4 110 5% 13%
Lewis Run (VA) 192.0 118 26% 85%
````` ::: ::: bibliography: references.bib[@kermorvant2023] ![](thumbnail.jpg)
